abstract.p: Lillian Lee Liss letter on Mary Gordon's May 29 article recalls thrift required in past and expresses gratitude for today's greater affluence

block.p: Mary Gordon's look back at her mother's economy of necessity (Op-Ed, May 29) expressed my own awe at the way money is spent today.

I remember how my mom collected the wrappers packed around fruit to use for toilet tissue: how every piece of paper had a second function. As the fifth girl in the family, I didn't wear a brand-new garment until I went to work. Eating out meant going to an aunt's house for dinner.
Mary Gordon's look back at her mother's economy of necessity (Op-Ed, May 29) expressed my own awe at the way money is spent today.

I remember how my mom collected the wrappers packed around fruit to use for toilet tissue: how every piece of paper had a second function. As the fifth girl in the family, I didn't wear a brand-new garment until I went to work. Eating out meant going to an aunt's house for dinner.

Although my children got more than I did, luxuries were few. When they bought homes for more than $100,000, I trembled with fear that they would lose them, trapped as I was in the Depression mentality.

People talk about the good old days. They were not all that good. Now I give gifts that cost more than I once spent on a year's worth of clothes. My mother would have looked on the salaries and pensions that constitute my earnings in wonderment. I still do, but with gratitude.
